description: This blended online/in-classroom graduate level course integrates principles of systems thinking with foundational concepts in patient safety. Utilizing complexity theories, students assess healthcare practices and identify factors that contribute to medical errors and impact patient safety. Using a clinical microsystem framework, learners assess a potential patient safety issue and create preventive systems. Lessons learned from the science of safety are utilized in developing strategies to enhance safe system redesign. Core competencies for all healthcare professionals are emphasized, content is applicable for all healthcare providers including, but not limited to, nurses, pharmacists, physicians, social workers and healthcare administrators, and may be taken as an elective by non-majors.
name: SYSTEMS THINKING IN PATIENT SAFETY

values.comments:
This blended online/in-classroom graduate level course integrates principles of systems thinking with foundational concepts in patient safety. Utilizing complexity theories, students assess healthcare practices and identify factors that contribute to medical errors and impact patient safety. Using a clinical microsystem framework, learners assess a potential patient safety issue and create preventive systems. Lessons learned from the science of safety are utilized in developing strategies to enhance safe system redesign. Core competencies for all healthcare professionals are emphasized, content is applicable for all healthcare providers including, but not limited to, nurses, pharmacists, physicians, social workers and healthcare administrators, and may be taken as an elective by non-majors.

	Students agreed that there was an excessive amount of work for this course; moreover, it was described as largely busywork that was minimally beneficial in terms of actual learning. Some students also stated that the readings were “redundant.”

	The instructors for this course received positive comments. According to the reviewers, they listened to student feedback and adjusted the unmanageable workload as the course progressed. However, the amount of in person instruction was unsatisfactory for several students, who did not like the online component.

	This is an elective course, though one student who found it particularly useful recommended it for all MSN and BSN students.

Using a clinical microsystem framework, learners assess a potential patient safety issue and create preventive systems. Lessons learned from the science of safety are utilized in developing strategies to enhance safe system redesign. Core competencies for all healthcare professionals are emphasized, content is applicable for all healthcare providers including, but not limited to, nurses, pharmacists, physicians, social workers and healthcare administrators, and may be taken as an elective by non-majors.

Overall students felt that there was a great degree of work required for the course, noting that “there were too man ‘little’ things on the to-do list.”  Another issue that cropped up was the feeling that there was inadequate in person contact with the teachers, and too much focus on the online assignments.

Students praised “Sue’s” “understanding and listening to feedback” as well as her skillful lecturing.

Overall, students felt that this course was “redundant” and “could have been condensed.”  Yet, on the other hand they also noted that it was “a must take course for all nursing leaders” and “was helpful in terms of critical thinking in application to the healthcare environment.”  Overall, the largest complaints were with the onerous workload and impersonality of the large online component which seemed to be universal; however, the students felt that Keim and her co-instructor Burke were “flexible” and “helpful.”
